hints_html:
The formula for the y-coordinate for the centroid is

\[\begin{aligned} \bar{y} = \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2} - g(x)^{2})\, dx\end{aligned}\]

valid when \(g(x) \leq f(x)\) on \(a \leq x \leq b\)
hints_raw:
The formula for the ''y''-coordinate for the centroid is

:<math>
\bar{y} = \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2} - g(x)^{2})\, dx
</math>

valid when <math> g(x) \leq f(x) </math> on <math> a \leq x \leq b </math>
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
Let \(f(x) = 1\) and \(g(x) = -e^{x}\). Notice that between 0 and 1, we have that \(g(x) \leq f(x)\) and so we have

\[\begin{aligned} \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{0}^{1}(f(x)^{2} - g(x)^{2})\, dx\\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\int_{0}^{1}(1^{2} - (-e^{x})^{2})\, dx\\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\int_{0}^{1}(1 - e^{2x})\, dx\\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\left.\left(x - \frac{e^{2x}}{2}\right) \right|_{0}^{1}\\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\left( \left(1 - \frac{e^{2(1)}}{2}\right) - \left(0 - \frac{e^{2(0)}}{2}\right) \right)\\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\left( 1 - \frac{e^{2}}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2e}\left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{e^{2}}{2} \right)\\ &= \frac{3-e^{2}}{4e}\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.

Let $f(x) = 1$ and $g(x) = -e^{x}$. Notice that between \emph{0} and
\emph{1}, we have that $g(x) \leq f(x)$ and so we have

\begin{align*}
\bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{0}^{1}(f(x)^{2} - g(x)^{2})\, dx\\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\int_{0}^{1}(1^{2} - (-e^{x})^{2})\, dx\\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\int_{0}^{1}(1 - e^{2x})\, dx\\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\left.\left(x - \frac{e^{2x}}{2}\right) \right|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\left( \left(1 - \frac{e^{2(1)}}{2}\right) - \left(0 - \frac{e^{2(0)}}{2}\right)  \right)\\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\left( 1 - \frac{e^{2}}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right) \\
&= \frac{1}{2e}\left( \frac{3}{2} - \frac{e^{2}}{2} \right)\\
&= \frac{3-e^{2}}{4e}
\end{align*}

completing the question.

statement_html: Find the y-coordinate of the centroid of the region bounded by the curves \(y = 1\) , \(y = -e^{x}\), \(x=0\) and \(x=1\). You may use the fact that the area of this region equals e.

that the area of this region equals \emph{e}.
